data.name: Journal Club 1 - Paper Selections
data.description:
Group Leaders - Post a link and/or pdf of the paper for your group to discuss this week.

Participants - Comment that you have received the link to the paper

Go to: https://pubs.acs.org/

Choose an area of interest, Choose a Journal that sounds interesting.

There are several different sections to note on the journal page:

  • ASAP means "As soon as publishable" so these are the newest accepted articles to the journal
  • Featured Content is a few selected highlights from the last full publication.  So these are noteworthy and recent.
  • "Most Read" is a good section to find articles that are broadly engaging.

Pick an article and share a link!
data.course_name: CHEM-203-01-2252 - Undergraduate Seminar I

data.name: Assignment - Career Plan
data.description:
Why work on a resume when you have a few more years of school?  At this point in your career and development, you have many opportunities to grow into the field that you are interested in!  Taking time now to explore career options and make a plan will allow you to build your resume to become a stronger candidate when the time comes to apply.

This objective has two components:

  • Complete Career Exploration using mynextmove.org
  • Submit a short Career Plan

Career Plan

For the final project, you need to create a short document that outlines the following components of your career plan:

  • Overview of potential career paths
    • What careers interest you?
    • What would this career entail?
  • Chart a path to achieving this career
    • What educational milestones would you need?
    • What extra-curricular development would prepare you?
  • What are the skills needed for this career?
    • How can you develop these skills?
    • Are there certifications that can highlight these skills?
  • What is your plan over the next 12 months to prepare yourself?
    • Dedicated section of your document
    • This includes your summer plans this year!
    • Be intentional & detailed! Specific internships or opportunities should be evaluated!

During Week 10, we will spend time in class sharing your career plans with your peers and discussing them.  Come prepared and this will be a good opportunity to refine your document before committing to a final submission.
data.course_name: CHEM-203-01-2252 - Undergraduate Seminar I

data.name: Assignment - Resume Final Draft
data.description:
Throughout this quarter, you will be editing a professional resume highlighting your chemistry-related skills!  A strong resume will equip you to apply for internships, REUs, and other programs of study.  Eventually, a strong resume will be vital to applying for Jobs and Graduate Programs!

Submit a PDF of your Final/Updated Resume.

In addition to your resume, you must submit a relevant job posting!
data.course_name: CHEM-203-01-2252 - Undergraduate Seminar I

data.name: Assignment - Technical Skills
data.description:
From Organic Chemistry (Sophomore Year) through Instrumental Analysis, you are expected to present information in a clear and professional manner.  Organization of information and the use of existing templates, make information easy to read.

We will learn how to use ChemDraw to create simple figures and structures that are ready for publication, as well as how to effectively use Templates in Microsoft Office to create accessible documents with easy generation of a table of contents.

To install ChemDraw, see ChemDraw Installation Instructions

ChemDraw

Part 1

  • Look up the Chemical Structure for any natural product or commercial drug.  (If you can't decide on a good one, Penicillin V is one of the most important molecular discoveries in recent history).
  • Use ChemDraw to recreate this structure
  • Use the Analysis window to note the Molecular Formula and Molecular Weight of the compound

Part 2

  • Choose a single reaction scheme (NOT mechanism) to recreate using ChemDraw.
    • The Reaction must include: at least 2 starting materials & reagent(s) to go over the arrow.
  • Once you have drawn out the reaction:
    • Select the reaction scheme. Go to “Structure -> Clean up Reaction” from the menu bar
    • Right click the reaction scheme.
      • Analysis -> Chemical Formula
      • Analysis -> Molecular Weight

Part 3

  • EXPLORE! Make ONE figure or scheme using one of ChemDraw’s other tools
  • Look through the toolbar to find templates and other drawing tools. Some example ideas:
    • TLC Plates, with multiple spots and Rf values
    • Try putting structures into each cell and then playing with the “Object -> align” commands
    • Clipware for Glassware images. Recreate a reaction set-up from Organic Lab!
    • Orbitals – Draw the HOMO or LUMO for a given compound with the orbital tools

WORD

Use the styles built into word (you can edit them if you’d like) to present your Chemdraw figures with the following guidelines:

  • Select the figure in chemdraw, copy and paste into Word.
    • Depending on if you use a Mac or PC, word handles these figures differently… but they should show up regardless of platform.
  • Include a Table of Contents that is built from the heading styles
  • Use at least 3 different sub-headings for sections
    • Heading 1 - Title of the Document
    • Heading 2 – Title for subsection
    • Heading 3 – Title for reflection of subsection
  • Include your name in the Header of the document
  • Insert page numbers into the Footer of the document

data.name: Assignment | About You Video
data.description:
Record and submit a 1-2 min. video URL from your favorite part of your home or place you can get to and cover these topics and more if you wish.

  • your name
  • where you grew up
  • what you want to get out of this class
  • a surprising thing that happened to you in the last 3 months.
  • your pump up song (if there's a clean-ish version I'll play it in class)
  • a story (and optional visual aid) about a favorite smell from your childhood

As an example, here is mine...About Me video

Upload your video to YouTube (unlisted) and submit the URL.
data.course_name: AGB-202-01-2238 - Introduction to Sales

data.name: Assignment | Ch. 1 Perceptions of Sales
data.description:
Using the textbox, submit the following:

  1. What 5 words come to mind when you think about the sales profession and salespeople?
  2. What was the BEST sales experience you've ever had, why, and what was the result?
  3. What was the WORST sales experience you've ever had, why, and what was the result?
  4. If you were a salesperson, what part of the job would be the HARDEST OR LEAST SATISFYING for you?
  5. If you were a salesperson, what part of the job would be the EASIEST OR MOST SATISFYING for you?

data.name: Assignment | Prospecting
data.description:
Article:  Prospecting Article

Please respond to these questions in the textbox.

What was the muddiest point of the article for you (the point you find the least clear and most confusing) in the article?

What was the most surprising statistic to you and why?

Why do YOU think prospecting is important in your own words?

Then, reflect on what you think the article missed or didn't say that you think is noteworthy.

data.name: Project | Paperclip Challenge
data.description:
The Famous Paperclip Challenge

Watch:  Yale School of Management article and video "Bigger & Better"

GROUP ASSIGNMENTS

The objective of this assignment is for your group to start with a paperclip, and after several trades over 2 weeks, end up with the biggest and best 'thing' you can. The final 'thing' does not need to be physical, but there must be something to represent the 'thing'. We will do the first trade in class and switch with your teammate the following week. Each teammate must do at least 3 trades and end up with an item with a value of at least $10.

You will utilize: Prospecting, rejection, elevator pitch, storytelling, persuasion, strategy, negotiation, teamwork, communication, feature/benefits, and closing.

Submission/Class Presentation - On Presentation Day, your group will present your Trail of Trades ending with your final biggest and best 'thing' to the class. To help with your presentation, submit a PDF to Canvas before class for me to pull up for your group. For your presentation, walk us through the Trail of Trades, one trade at a time, with each slide showing a picture of the 'thing', the team member making the deal, and its value. Last, give us a brief reflection on 2 take-aways from this project. The class will vote on a category winner for each of these categories:  size, value, and creativity.

Canvas Submission - In Canvas, only 1 person from your group needs to submit your team PDF. Please submit it before Thursday's class so I can pull up your submission for your presentation in class. Otherwise, it officially needs to be submitted by midnight on Friday.

Rubric:  Each group will get full credit for participating but both students need to present the Trail of Trades.

data.name: Week 1 Group Report | Pigments
data.description:
(Guided) Lab Report #1. This is your first group report, but don't worry!  It's "guided" for you to provide some direction on the general approach and organization of our lab reports.  You only need to submit ONE copy of BOTH the written report and the results per group.

Please do the following (as a group!):

**Read this article from Oxford University about plagiarism before starting any writing!**

1. Fill in your responses to the report "prompts" in the Guided Report you received in class this week. Use the provided Report Guide to help!
2. Type up your responses to the review questions and print them out. You can find the review questions in the Week 1 Review Questions page.
3. Complete the Results sheet for lab #1 (pg 3-4 from your purchased Report Booklet). 
4. Staple all items (#1-3) and submit in class in Week 2


You ARE doing this in groups, so please distribute the work evenly and fairly!

data.name: AIR
data.description: Product of a committed step in purine biosynthesis produced from PRPP, glutamine, glycine, formate, and ATP; intermediate used toward IMP.

Committed 
Step!

PRPP + 2 Glutamine + 
Glycine + Formate + 3 ATP 
→ AIR

data.name: Inosinate (IMP)

aliases: Inosine precursor to AMP and GMP

Inosinate (IMP)

our precursor to AMP and GMP

data.name: Nucleotide biosynthesis
data.description: Biosynthesis of purine and pyrimidine nucleotides, including formation of triphosphates and deoxyribonucleotides and pathway regulation.

sources.source_document: Nucleotide Biosynthesis (slides text provided by user)
sources.section_title: Nucleotide Biosynthesis / Learning Objectives
sources.raw_text:
Learning Objectives

1. Know the building blocks for the biosynthesis of both purine and 

pyrimidine nucleotides.

2. Identify the differences between purine and pyrimidine synthesis 

pathways.

3. Be able to describe the structure and function of ribonucleotide 

reductase.

4. Understand how enzymes within the biosynthetic pathways are 

regulated.

data.name: Nucleotide biosynthesis pathways as pharmaceutical targets

data.name: 5-phosphoribosyl-1-pyrophosphate (PRPP)
data.description: Donor of sugar and phosphate used in nucleoside monophosphate formation; purine rings are built directly onto PRPP and pyrimidine bases are condensed with PRPP.

sources.source_document: Nucleotide Biosynthesis (slides text provided by user)
sources.section_title: Warm Up / PRPP
sources.raw_text:
In all nucleoside monophosphates, the sugar and 
phosphate come from PRPP

5-phosphoribosyl-1-pyrophosphate

data.name: Purine
data.description: Category of bases; attaches to sugar via N9.

sources.section_title: Bases can be categorized into purines and pyrimidines
sources.raw_text:
Bases can be categorized into purines and pyrimidines

Purines attach to the sugar via N9

data.name: Purine biosynthesis
data.description: Pathway in which the purine ring is built directly onto PRPP and proceeds through AIR to inosinate (IMP), which is a precursor to AMP and GMP.

sources.source_document: Nucleotide Biosynthesis (slides text provided by user)
sources.section_title: Purine biosynthesis requires components from many sources
sources.raw_text:
Purine biosynthesis requires components from many 
sources

Built directly onto PRPP

... 

PRPP + 2 Glutamine + 
Glycine + Formate + 3 ATP 
→ AIR

...

AIR + CO2 + Aspartate 
+ Formate + ATP → 
Inosinate (IMP)

Inosine – 
our precursor to AMP and GMP

data.name: Pyrimidine
data.description: Category of bases; attaches to sugar via N1.

sources.section_title: Bases can be categorized into purines and pyrimidines
sources.raw_text:
Bases can be categorized into purines and pyrimidines

Pyrimidines attach to the sugar via N1

data.name: Pyrimidine biosynthesis
data.description: Pathway in which the pyrimidine base is built first and then condensed with PRPP; described as requiring input from two precursor molecules.

sources.source_document: Nucleotide Biosynthesis (slides text provided by user)
sources.section_title: Pyrimidine biosynthesis only requires input from two precursor molecules
sources.raw_text:
Pyrimidine biosynthesis only requires input from two 
precursor molecules

Base is built first, then condensed with PRPP

data.name: Ribonucleotide reductase
data.description: Enzyme that converts ribonucleoside diphosphates (NDP) to deoxyribonucleoside diphosphates (dNDP); described as a heterotetramer and as ensuring a balanced pool of dNTPs.

sources.source_document: Nucleotide Biosynthesis (slides text provided by user)
sources.section_title: Part IV: Creating triphosphates and deoxy triphosphates / Ribonucleotide reductase

Deoxynucleotides can only 
be formed from 
ribonucleoside diphosphates
...
+ ATP
ribonucleotide 
reductase
...
Ribonucleotide reductase is a heterotetramer

NDP                      dNDP

Ribonucleotide reductase ensures that we have balanced 
pool of dNTPs
